net.hudup.core.evaluate

Class DefaultMetric

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.hudup.core.alg.AlgAbstract
      • net.hudup.core.evaluate.MetricAbstract
        • net.hudup.core.evaluate.DefaultMetric
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.rmi.Remote, java.util.EventListener, Alg, AlgRemote, AlgRemoteTask, SetupAlgListener, Exportable, Metric, MetricRemote, MetricRemoteTask
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    Accuracy, Accuracy, ArrayMetric, ExactRecallMetric, HudupRecallMetric, MetaMetric, TimeMetric, TwoArrayMetric, VectorMetric

    public abstract class DefaultMetric
extends MetricAbstract
    Note, the abstract class of Metric interface is {code AbstractMetric}. Three implemented classes of Metric which inherit from AbstractMetric are DefaultMetric, MetaMetric, and MetricWrapper as follows:
    • This DefaultMetric class is default partial implementation of single Metric.
    • MetaMetric class is a complex Metric which contains other metrics.
    • In some situations, if metric requires complicated implementation, it is wrapped by MetricWrapper class.
    The most important aspect of this default metric is that default metric provides the method recalc0(MetricValue). The MetricRemoteTask.recalc(Object...) method will call the #recalc0(MetricValue) method. The #recalc0(MetricValue) method is to accumulate metric value at each iteration.
    Version:
    10.0
    Author:
    Loc Nguyen
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

    • Method Detail

      • getCurrentValue

        public MetricValue getCurrentValue()
                            throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        Description copied from interface: MetricRemoteTask
        Methods MetricRemoteTask.getAccumValue() and MetricRemoteTask.getAccumValue() return accumulative value and current value of metric. After each time metric is re-calculated by MetricRemoteTask.recalc(Object...) method, accumulative value and current value can be changed. For example, a sample metric receives values 3, 1, 2 at the first, second, and third calculations. At the fourth calculation if MetricRemoteTask.recalc(Object...) produces value 2, the MetricRemoteTask.getCurrentValue() will return 2 and the MetricRemoteTask.getAccumValue() will return 3 + 1 + 2 + 2 = 8. Methods MetricRemoteTask.getAccumValue() and MetricRemoteTask.getCurrentValue() can return any thing and so their returned value is represented by MetricValue interface. How to implement MetricValue is dependent on concrete application.
        Returns:
        current MetricValue
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException - if any error raises.

      • getAccumValue

        public MetricValue getAccumValue()
                          throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        Description copied from interface: MetricRemoteTask
        Methods MetricRemoteTask.getAccumValue() and MetricRemoteTask.getAccumValue() return accumulative value and current value of metric. After each time metric is re-calculated by MetricRemoteTask.recalc(Object...) method, accumulative value and current value can be changed. For example, a sample metric receives values 3, 1, 2 at the first, second, and third calculations. At the fourth calculation if MetricRemoteTask.recalc(Object...) produces value 2, the MetricRemoteTask.getCurrentValue() will return 2 and the MetricRemoteTask.getAccumValue() will return 3 + 1 + 2 + 2 = 8. Methods MetricRemoteTask.getAccumValue() and MetricRemoteTask.getCurrentValue() can return any thing and so their returned value is represented by MetricValue interface. How to implement MetricValue is dependent on concrete application.
        Returns:
        accumulated MetricValue
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException - if any error raises.

      • recalc0

        protected boolean recalc0(MetricValue metricValue)
                   throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        The MetricRemoteTask.recalc(Object...) method will call the recalc0(MetricValue) method. This method is to accumulate metric value at each iteration.
        Parameters:
        metricValue - specified metric value.
        Returns:
        whether calculating successfully.
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException - if any error raises.
